pot are stored with their protective domes on, for safety.

In the event power is lost at the VNCD, an alarm will alert the control room.  Loss of power will cause the backup generator to take over powering the entire station.  The chlorine scrubber will still be fully functional if needed, with no safety consequences.

The LAAFP control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
¿	Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
¿	Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
¿	Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
¿	Performance of process hazard analysis review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
¿	State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
¿	Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.
¿	High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.
¿	A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.
¿	An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.
¿	An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors and alarms with remote monitoring, use of Midland and Halogen valve actuators; operation of three dry media chlorine

um downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released and the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve.

Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorine room and the chlorinator room, which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP's Control Room. Leak sensors are also provided in the diffuser vault.

The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs of chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 

In the event power is lost at the VNCS #2, UPS power will maintain continuous power to all instrumentation and alarm systems while a backup generator will automatically start and take over powering the entire facility.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

The LAAFP control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

The Van Norman Chemical Depot
The Van Norman Chemical Depot is a structure used for the storage of various chemicals used by the LADWP.  The Depot includes a large chlorine container storage room for receipt, storage and distribution of unopened chlorine one-ton containers and up to 150-lb cylinders. There are no chlorination processes at the facility.

The Depot is equipped with chlorine leak detectors, which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP's Control Room.  The Depot is also equipped with a one-ton capacity dry media chlorine main scrubber, which is activated automatically in the event of a chlorine leak inside the Depot. Containers are moved about inside the building using a bridge crane system; thus, reducing the probability of accidents involving chlorine containers.  Additionally, all containers in the De

to evaporators.  The gas discharge piping from the evaporators supply pressurized chlorine gas to the chlorinators through regulating valves.  A gas header from the bulk tank serves as a backup supply and automatically takes over when the evaporator is shut off due to a low temperature condition.  The bank of one-ton containers can also feed liquid or gas through the header system to the evaporators.

Chlorine injectors located at the three injection vaults.  The injectors provide vacuum which draws chlorine gas from the chlorinators into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  The solution is piped through diffusers into the various water pipelines. 
 
Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorinator and chlorine storage rooms, as well as in the vaults.  The detector signals an alarm by activating (1) a flashing red light over the entry door to the building, (2) an audible alarm within the chlorination building, and (3) an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant Control Room.

A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has been installed at the LAROCS. MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve.  It can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm.

In the event power is lost at the Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  Loss of power will cause the backup generator to take over powering the entire station.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

The LAAFP control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

The Van Norman Chloraminati

on Station #1
The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of one-ton containers plus additional spare one-ton containers. The containers in the two feed banks are equipped with Halogen Systems valve actuators that automatically close the ton-container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room. The spare ton-containers are not equipped with these actuators, as these containers are not connected to the process.

Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from one bank of ton-containers to a piping header that leads to evaporators. The gas discharge piping from the evaporators supply pressurized chlorine gas to vacuum regulating valves (evaporator actuated vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit) that reduce the pressure to a vacuum.  Vacuum piping continues to the chlorinators.  A gas header from the second bank of ton-containers serves as a backup supply and automatically takes over when the evaporator is shut off due to a low temperature condition. This header is also equipped with vacuum regulating valves (standby vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit) that reduce the pressure to a vacuum before it reaches the chlorinators. The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine. From here, gas is pulled by vacuum to injectors located in remote cabinets on top of the diffuser vaults. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released and the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve.

Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorine room and the chlorinator room,  which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP's Control Room. Leak sensors are also provided in the diffuser vaults. 

The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs of

main scrubbers; and two dry media chlorine mini-scrubbers.

Process and Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facilities) are on file at the facility.  The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.
Process Hazard Analysis 

In 2009, detailed process hazard analyses (PHAs) were conducted for the LAAFP, LAROCS and VNCD.  PHAs for VNCS #1 and VNCS #2 were performed in December 2005 and January 2006, based on design drawings. PHAs for VNCS #1 and VNCS #2 were reviewed on April 22, 2011 and June 10, 2011, after these processes were constructed. PHAs for the above five processes were again reviewed on the following dates: PHA for LAAFP and VNCD on January 17, 2014; PHA for LAROCS on January 23, 2014 and April 11, 2014; and PHA for VNCS#1 and VNCS#2 on February 28, 2014. These PHAs will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process. A list of recommended actions was developed in January 2014 through April 2014 to further improve the chlorine safety and staff is currently reviewing these recommendations. Staff will document the completion of the recommended actions.
Seismic walkthroughs for the above five processes were completed in May 2014, based on the LEPC Region 1 guidance document, and recommendations are being evaluated for

implementation.

Operating Procedures
The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for the LAAFP processes that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information.   Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual are as follows:
¿	Delivery of Chlorine.
¿	Railcar Connections
¿	Bulk Tank Connections
¿	Container Connections.
¿	Initial Startup Procedure.
¿	Normal Operation.
¿	Normal Shutdown.
¿	Temporary Operations.
¿	Emergency Operations.
¿	Emergency Shutdown.
¿	Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.

Training 
	The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above.  The LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes, as a minimum, the following elements:
¿	Safety Information.
¿	Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
¿	Maintenance Procedures.
¿	Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.
¿	RMP Program contents.
¿	Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures before startup of a process after major modifications.  
  
Contractors
The LADWP contractors' procedures specify th

e information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program
The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation.  The required conditions prior to startup include the following:

¿	Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
¿	Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
¿	A PHA has been performed for new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup.
¿	At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
¿	Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.
These procedures ensure that no new and/or significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 
Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.

Maintenance 
The LADWP operates a maintenance program, MAXIMO Program that generates a work order for performing the pre

ventive maintenance routine, which occurs after a designated time past the closing of the previous work order for that particular maintenance process.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The water treatment supervisors are responsible for the maintenance of the chlorination system.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual every 2 to 10 years, and on as-needed basis.  These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets onsite and provide a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided onsite for Operator quick reference.

The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 
Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations.  The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 
The LADWP MOC procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, process safety i

nformation, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits
The LADWP certifies at a minimum of every three years (or less) that compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.
The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:
¿	Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
¿	Onsite Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
¿	Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.
Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.  

Incident Investigation
The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident

investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.
Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the LAAFP processes during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary
The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  
As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:

(a)	An emergency response plan is maintained at each facility, including the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:
¿	Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
¿	Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
¿	Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
¿	Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
¿	Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
¿	Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
¿	Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 
(c)	Training in relevant proce

dures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.
(d)	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As part of updating the 2004 Risk Management Program, PHA s were performed in 2009 for the LAAFP, VNCD and LAROCS chlorination systems. Based on 2009 PHAs, additional recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. All the above recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by the LADWP, including the installation and operation of the dry media chlorine mini-scrubbers at the LAAFP and LAROCS. As part of updating the 2009 Risk Management Program, PHAs were performed in 2011 for the VNCS#1 and VNCS#2 chlorination systems.  Based on 2011 PHAs, additional recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. All the above recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by the LADWP. Additionally, 23 recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in January 2014 through April 2014, when the PHAs were reviewed for the five processes. Based on the 2014 seismic assessment, nine recommendations were also made to improve chlorine safety. It is expected that all the recommendations will be evaluated by December 2014 and implemented by June 2015.  The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the chlorination and storage systems.

Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards. Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations. The LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes in providing safe drinking water.  The LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) facility chlorine handling processes are subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements. The facilities subject to the EPA and the CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs).  The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  

The LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant facility complex now consists of four different chlorination stations and one chemical depot: (1) the LAAFP facility; (2)  the Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station (LAROCS); (3) the Van Norman Chemical Depot (VNCD); (4) the Van Norman Chloramination Station # 1 (VNCS#1); and (5) the Van Norman Chloramination Station #2 (VNCS#2). The LADWP prepared and submitted the RMPs for the LAAFP, LAROCS and VNCD facilities in June 1999, June 2004, and June 2009. Subsequent to the preparation of the RMP in June 2009, the LAFFP facility was modified and two additional chlorination processes at the LAAFP complex (VNCS#1 and VNCS#2) were added. The LADWP, therefore, prepared and submitted

and the California OSHA PSM regulations. Additional details of the five processes are provided below.

The Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant
Liquid chlorine is supplied to the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant in 90-ton railcars with a backup of one-ton containers for the chlorination process.  Liquid or gaseous chlorine is withdrawn from the railcars. Midland valve actuators are connected to both the liquid and gas connections on the railcars.  The Midland valve actuators will close on the railcar and stop the flow of chlorine when 10 ppm of chlorine is detected in the area.  The Midland valve actuators can also be manually triggered from the following three locations: (1) Rail Car Platform (2) Chlorinator room, and (3) Control Room. In addition to the Midland actuators, there are three Jamesbury actuators on the hard piping to the flex hoses. The detection of 10 ppm of chlorine will automatically close the ball valves connecting the hard piping to the flex hoses, stopping the possible backflow of chlorine, in case a crack developed in the flex hose. 
Liquid chlorine travels under pressure to evaporator units, while gaseous chlorine can be withdrawn directly to the chlorinators.  The evaporators vaporize the liquid in a water bath to form a superheated gas which passes through a pressure reducing valve and a evaporator activated vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, and then to the chlorinators.  Chlorine gas from the vacuum regulating valve is pulled by vacuum to the chlorinators. The chlorinators regulate the gas flow and discharge it to the injection lines at the appropriate rate.  Chlorine gas from the chlorinators is pulled by vacuum to injectors located on the downstream piping at various chlorine application points.  It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released and the vacuum regulating valve with check-r

an update of the June 2009 RMP in December 2011, which included all the required information for the VNCS#1 and VNCS#2 chlorination systems. The LADWP prepared Program Level 3 RMPs because the LAAFP processes are subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. This 2014 RMP is an update of the RMPs submitted in June 2009 and December 2011, and includes updated information for all the five LAAFP processes. The 2014 RMP also demonstrates compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary:
 
¿	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
¿	General facility and regulated substances information.
¿	Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
¿	Five-year accident history summary.
¿	Emergency response program summary.
¿	Planned changes to improve safety.

As described above, the LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant facility consists of four different chlorination stations and one chemical depot; the LAAFP facility, the LAROCS, the VNCS #1, the VNCS#2, and the VNCD. The above information for the five LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant facilities is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and the EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures. 
 
The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with

the EPA and the CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The emergency response plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department).  The LAAFP facilities have an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information
The five LAAFP processes are located in the same complex adjacent to the Los Angeles Reservoir in Sylmar, California.  The Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant treats up to 600 million gallons per day of water from the Los Angeles Owens River Aqueduct or from the Metropolitan Water District. Liquid chlorine is delivered to the plant in 90-ton railcars or by truck in one-ton containers. The 90-ton railcar is the largest vessel (container) online. 

The Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station serves to chlorinate water in a single 120 diameter pipeline exiting the reservoir.  The treated water is then piped into the distribution network which serves much of the San Fernando Valley with potable water and feeds other reservoirs.  It also chlorinates the outlet flow from the Van Norman Bypass Reservoir and another pipeline called the Rinaldi Trunk Line.  This station stores chlorine in a 25-ton bulk storage tank; it can also store one-ton chlorine containers to be used when the bulk tank is taken out of service for maintenance or repair. The 25-ton bulk tank is the largest vessel (container) online. 

The Van Norman Chloramination Station #1 is used to establish a chloramine residual in the treated water. The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of one-ton containers plus additional spare ton-containers. The one-ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site. Each of the containers in the two feed banks are equipped with Halogen Syst

ems valve actuators that automatically close the ton-container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room. The spare ton-containers are not equipped with these actuators, as these containers cannot be connected to the process in the storage location.

The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs of chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 
The Van Norman Chloramination Station #2 is used to establish a chloramine residual in the treated water. This station uses chlorine in one-ton containers. The one-ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site. Each of the containers in the two feed banks are equipped with Halogen Systems valve actuators that automatically close the ton-container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room.

The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs of chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 
The Van Norman Chemical Depot is used for storage of unopened one-ton chlorine containers and 150-lb cylinders in addition to various other chemicals.   The one-ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site.  The depot is equipped with a one-ton capacity dry media chlorine scrubber. The chlorine is activated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm.

All the five LAAFP processes currently store and/or use chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and the CalARP Program rules.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the LAAFP processes at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and the CalARP regulations. It also exceeds the specified threshold quantity of the federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard. Thus, the LAAFP processes are subject to the federal

elief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve.
Multiple chlorine leak detectors continuously monitor the railcar area, ton container storage area, chlorine pipe trench, and the chlorination room in the existing system.  They alarm locally as well as at the operator's console in the control room. 

A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has been installed at the LAAFP chlorination room. MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve.  It can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.

In the event power is lost at the LAAFP facility, two backup generators will automatically start and take over powering the entire facility.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.
The LAAFP control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

The Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station
At the Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station the primary supply of liquid chlorine is from a 25-ton capacity bulk tank.  A gas line is also connected to the bulk tank to serve as a backup supply if the liquid supply is disabled.  Additionally, one-ton containers can be connected to a liquid feed header in the event the bulk tank is taken out of service for maintenance.  Midland valve actuators are connected to both the liquid and gas connections on the bulk tank.  The Midland valve actuators will close on the bulk container when the chlorine sensors detect 10 ppm of chlorine in the chlorine storage room. 
Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from the bulk tank to a piping header that leads

chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 
In the event power is lost at the VNCS#1, UPS power will maintain continuous power to all instrumentation and alarm systems while a backup generator will automatically start and take over powering the entire facility.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

The LAAFP control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

The Van Norman Chloramination Station #2
The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of one-ton containers plus additional spare one-ton containers. The containers in the two feed banks are equipped with Halogen Systems valve actuators that automatically close the ton-container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room. The spare ton-containers are not equipped with these actuators, as these containers are not connected to the process.

Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from one bank of ton-containers to a piping header that leads to evaporators.  The gas discharge piping from the evaporators supply pressurized chlorine gas to vacuum regulating valves (evaporator actuated vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit) that reduce the pressure to a vacuum. Vacuum piping continues to the chlorinators. A gas header from the second bank of ton-containers serves as a backup supply and automatically takes over when the evaporator is shut off due to a low temperature condition. This header is also equipped with vacuum regulating valves (standby vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit) that reduce the pressure to a vacuum before it reaches the chlorinators. The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine. From here, gas is pulled by vacuum to injectors located in remote cabinets on top of the diffuser vaults. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacu
